When did you notice the plane was in trouble?
Well, I was actually driving parallel to the plane on a road, a public access road, in the airport, and I just happened to be watching it.
As, you know, we drive into the airport, we always just seem to watch the planes as they land and take off while we're driving in.
And I was--the weather was really bad.
It was raining hard.
And I was just one--thinking to myself, `Wow, that plane's out in this weather?
And I was just sort of watching it, watching the road, watching the plane.

It just kept going and going, and I was watching it.
There was lightning strikes around and all of a sudden, lightning hit the plane off in the distance, I saw.
Then there was some smoke, and it just continued on and just disappeared right down the hill from my view.
So what did you do?
Well, I was just like, `Oh, my God, hit by lightning!

And then it was just sort of--we were--I was behind about three or four cars, and after it went down, like, about, I don't know, 30 seconds later, we were just turning the curves where the plane went down, and everybody was stopping.
There was smoke, and people were trying to reverse, get out of the way.

I just started zigzagging around these people on the curve in the opposite lane and finally got over to where the plane had broken through the fence and the concrete to go through the gully, and I just sort of parked in there and looked, and saw the tail section sticking up, a little bit of fire, and I was like, `Oh, my God.
